Award.AwardTitle: Novel Solitonic Waveguides Based on Granular Phononic Crystals

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to simulate and measure the formation of acoustic solitons in two-dimensional granular waveguides. The PIs will design and fabricate hexagonally packed granular lattices "defined as granular phononic crystals" contained in a narrow channel. The PIs will unveil unique soliton formation and transmission mechanisms in the assembled granular architectures. The fundamental understanding of soliton propagation will enable a new class of waveguides that can filter, delay, and redirect acoustic solitons in a controllable and efficient manner. The PIs will achieve this research goal by developing an advanced discrete element model (DEM) and a novel digital image correlation (DIC) technique. Based on molecular dynamics techniques, the DEM will simulate the propagation of solitons under the full consideration of axial and rotational dynamics of tightly packed, frictional particles. The PIs will verify the numerical simulation results by the DIC techniques that measure extremely small particle displacements at high sampling rates.

From the viewpoint of physics, the findings in this study will contribute to the advancement of nonlinear mechanics of granular media based on the Lagrangian description of particle dynamics. With a view towards potential engineering applications, the fabricated solitonic waveguide can open a new paradigm in mechanical wave filtering, acoustic imaging, and nondestructive evaluation by leveraging an added degree of freedom in controlling mechanical waves. Besides contributing to science and engineering, the research activities will also have a broader impact on educating students. The PIs will recruit and train underrepresented students via student services and programs at the University of South Carolina (USC). The knowledge and product obtained from this work will be integrated into the new graduate program in aerospace engineering at USC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the PIs investigated how to control the mechanical properties of nonlinear waves that propagate in granular phononic crystals. Granular phononic crystals are defined as an assembly of systematically arranged discrete particles, which serve as an excellent platform to support various types of waves and vibrations (i.e., phonon). Nonlinear wave dynamics in such discrete granular media has not been fully explored by previous studies. The PIs used analytical, numerical, and experimental tools to unveil novel wave dynamics in granular phononic crystals.

Specific details of the technical approaches taken by the PIs’ teams are as below:

- Analytical approach: The PIs employed various techniques, such as a long-wave approximation and an asymptotic analysis, to obtain theoretical insights in the nonlinear wave dynamics of the granular phononic crystals.

- Computational approach: For the simplification of numerical calculations, we employed a discrete element analysis, which approximates granular particles into lumped massed that are connected by nonlinear springs. This is similar to the numerical computation approach used in molecular dynamics.

- Experimental approach: The most novel aspect of this project is the introduction of advanced experimental techniques to measure the dynamics of granular media via non-contact methods (e.g., high speed photography and laser Doppler vibrometry as shown in the Figure below). By using these techniques, the PIs were successfully able to visualize novel wave dynamics in granular phononic crystals in an accurate and controllable manner.

Some of the highlights of the new findings through this study are listed below:

- Discovery of dark breathers: Dark breathers are characterized by spatially localized, temporally periodic pulses as shown in the second panel of the figure below. This implies that granular phononic crystals that we designed and fabricated in this project can be used for energy harvesting purposes by localizing nonlinear vibration energy.

- Unveiling nonlinear wave propagation in 2D granular architectures: When researchers investigate wave propagation in closely packed granular media, they often neglect the effect of particles’ rotation and the associated friction effect. The PIs validated through numerical simulations and experimental demonstrations that such rotational dynamics is crucial in accurately capturing the wave propagation phenomena in even highly ordered granular media.

- Turbulence-like wave dynamics in diatomic granular crystals: Turbulence is a phenomenon characterized by energy cascades in different length and time scales, normally witnessed in fluids. We demonstrated that similar cascading effects can be observed in diatomic granular crystals, showing low- to high- frequency/wavenumber energy re-distribution (see the third and fourth panels in the Figure below for the experimental setup and numerical calculation of this turbulence phenomenon). This can be a highly useful mechanism to dissipate vibrational or impact energy without resorting to material damping.

The findings from this study can contribute to enhancing our understanding of nonlinear wave dynamics in granular phononic crystals. The analytical, numerical, and experimental toolsets developed in this study can be useful in general studies of granular and other types of media. The impact of the developed principles is that we shed light on the nonlinear aspect of such artificially fabricated materials, which can potentially open new avenues to localizing, attenuating, and modulating stress waves in various engineering applications. Examples of such applications include energy harvesting, impact mitigation, and mechanical wave filtering.
